comments.commentBody: What is SOD?

"... but I haven't found many [on the left] that are antagonistic to freedom of religion as long as the theists do not wish to impose their beliefs on other people"

****
Depends on how you define "impose their beliefs".

When the mere display of a symbol or the speaking of a word becomes an imposition, I'd say they very much wish to remove religion entirely from the public sphere.

One example is the Plano, Texas, elementary school case where pencils, on which "Jesus is the reason for the season" was written, were confiscated. The school also prohibited one class from writing "Merry Christmas" on cards for US troops in Iraq.

In Scarsdale, NY, a parent was prohibited from stating that Christmas is the celebration of the birth of Jesus Christ when visiting her child's class to talk about Christmas at holiday time. She was permitted to talk about her Christmas "traditions" (cookie baking, I presume) but not permitted to discuss the religious significance of the holiday.

AAC: you've provided three anecdotes that don't indicate anything other than that in three cases, teachers didn't permit the discussion of religion in their classes. Without explaining the context in which the incidents took place, you are expecting your readers to agree with your assumptions.

I, however, take your examples with several grains of salt.

1) If someone brought pencils to my daughter's class saying "Jesus is the reason for the season" and distributed or otherwise made an issue of them, I'd have complained, because that would constitute proselytizing in a public school classroom. 2) Perhaps the teacher who didn't want students wishing the troops "Merry Christmas" was cognizant that some--perhaps many--of the troops are not Christian, and therefore suggested they use a more inclusive greeting. 3) Maybe the parent who came in to talk about Christmas had been invited to talk about traditions, not about the birth of the savior, Jesus.

I don't know whether you've thought much about what it's like to be a non-Christian child in a public elementary school classroom when Christian songs and religious references are assumed to apply to everyone. For those students, it can be uncomfortable and upsetting. For the rest of us, there's always the fact that the Supreme Court has ruled many times on the unconstitutionality of religious practice in public school classrooms.

We have a lot more serious challenges to face in this country than the fictitious "war on Christmas."

ACC: There is so much misleading information in your post, I can only counter with the PolitiFact summary of this issue:

"So, can kids pray and openly celebrate Christmas in school? Absolutely, we conclude, though public school officials are barred from advancing a religion or making children pray or celebrate solely the Christian aspects of Christmas.

The Supreme Court has not held that students can’t pray; Perry’s home state even has laws protecting that right. The highest court also hasn’t held that kids can’t openly celebrate Christmas at school."

http://www.politifact.com/texas/statements/2011/dec/09/rick-perry/rick-p...

The bottom line is that you can't force kids to pray but they are free to pray if they want to. You can't force public school kids to observe Christmas any more than you can force them to observe Hannakah, Ramadan or Kwanzaa. And, although public schools can't promote a specific religion, they are free to teach classes about religions. (I don't know where you went to school but at the NYC public schools I attended we covered Christmas and Hannakah pretty thoroughly, along with the Winter Solstice. I don't know if Kwanzaa was much celebrated then - it may have just come in toward the end. I remember it at college.)

No one is destroying religious freedom except those who are trying to impose their religious beliefs on others by law. Now, that really would be un-American.

I'm sure there must be some members of the left that are so antagonistic to religion that their very atheism becomes a form of absolutism that tolerates no dissent, but I haven't found many that are antagonistic to freedom of religion as long as the theists do not wish to impose their beliefs on other people.

But the vast majority of people on the left, whether adherents of a particular faith or not, aren't looking to remove religious principles as a means of establishing rational arguments for how our country should be governed.

Once they enter the public sphere, however, those principles are no longer sacrosanct, and the positions derived from those principles must be subject to negotiation or the political process itself will grind to a halt.

That's a significant difference from the religious right, who take the position that it should be my way or the highway, and feel put upon when they can't convince a majority of the legislative bodies to agree with their positions, they can't elect a president or governor who will try to implement their positions, or they can't convince a court that their position on an issue falls within the bounds of our constitution.

Therein lies a crucial distinction. The left and right are not polar opposites in a two dimensional plane. They function as separate spheres in three dimensional space, with the left having far more overlap with the center than the right could ever have.

Reason (2) might be a footnote, as by definition it's a small minority.
Your three points are the truth in a nutshell.  You nailed it perfectly.  And this is why I think the republicans stand a very good chance of winning the election.

The Republicans are placing a large bet. They are gambling that a majority of the voters in November is comprised of people who (1) are too dense to understand the economic fallacies behind the Republican approach or (2) are direct beneficiaries of the Republican top-down class warfare or (3) are so consumed by their hatred of Barack Obama that they gladly vote against their own economic self-interest.

The scary thing is the Republicans may turn out to be right, unless Democrats begin to show more energy in making their voices heard.

People have to have money to spend. Companies can produce until they run out of capital, but if no one is buying because they are broke, no sales. To stay in business, to keep going, businesses must reduce sales prices to the point that their goods can be sold. So policies that put money into the hands of the most potential buyers, will generate sales. Economic theory is just that, a theory.

ANetliner: I always enjoy your analytical comments in this section of the NYT. Are you an academic economist teaching in the DC area?

Now, regarding your sound recommendation of directing tax cuts to the lower half of the income distribution. How do you do this in the current US political system? from sunny Florianopolis, Brazil, it seems to me that neither democrats nor republicans are concerned about the 99%. What you are proposing is exactly the (successfuly) income distribution policy taking place in Brazil since PT/Pres Lula came to power in 2003.

Cheers,

Uzi Nogueira
nogueirauzi@hotmail.com

Uzi Nogueira

Tim,  How do you increase demand for that supply if you don't leave money in the hands of the would-be purchasers?  They can supply  a million widgets, but if there aren't enough people with money to buy those widgets, the widgets will sit on a shelf, unsold.  The very rich won't even buy those widgets, they have plenty already.   Conversely, if everyone has enough money to buy a widget or two, the demand will rise, and the company will need to produce more widgets to meet the demand.  Companies will need more workers to make the widgets, sell the widgets, ship the widgets, etc........

What most Americans and many economists miss is that consumer demand is what generates growth.  Thus, tax cuts are best directed at the lower half of the income distribution, where they will be spent. Top earners will spend too, even if their taxes remain high.  I hope that fiscal policy continues to encourage most Americans to spend.

Really?
If that were indeed the case about the current president, then how could it possibly be that for three years. even he was unable to produce a BC?
How could it be that no one has yet laid eyes on his college transcripts?

Your comments are emblematic of wishful thinking based on little more than a personal faith in the vetting system.

There may be no conspiracy but there sure isn't much documentation about any vetting let alone about the 44th president himself.

As you point out Andrew, some people are so consumed with hatred and bigotry they will stop at nothing to further their agenda.

It has not occurred to these lower life forms that a presidential candidate is investigated so thoroughly that they know things about him that he does not even know himself.

The FBI, the Secret Service, the NSA, the DOD, even the CIA and other classified agencies collect information on him. The president is privy to the most sensitive security information available. If there was a problem with his citizenship, it would be known.

Unfortunately there are enough people who will believe any conspiracy theory, or any slur that will justify their prejudices, they will believe it, and will spread it as fact. It is interesting that most of them call themselves Republicans. One must ask what is it about being a Republican that causes this sort of mental illness?

Maybe I have it backward, why does mental illness cause people to become Republicans?

Now there is a good subject for a Masters thesis.

It is amusing  that there are still people making this argument when the policies you defend have repeatedly produced the opposite of what you claim they will. Arguing that cutting corporate taxes and lower taxes for the rich will boost the economy is the modern equivalent of insisting the sun revolves around the earth.

"Do Republicans really want to be associated with Rush Limbaugh as the face and voice of their party? "    Well, unless the Republicans or any Republican criticizes Limbaugh for his tasteless personal attack on the law student, I would guess that they really do want to be associated with him.   Their individual and collecive failure to take Limbaugh to task says something about the Republican leaders.

What is so extraordinary in the anti-contraception and denial of women's healthcare attack, is that it is being promulgated mostly by orthodox men and some women who say that "roma loucta est, causa finita est" or "Rome has spoken, the case is closed."

Women have unique reproductive organs and problematic issues that arise during their fertile years, for years after and even entire lifetimes. It seems the church has overlooked a huge host of female-specific issues as it laid down its Humana Vitae doctrine over the last 2,000 years.

Let me get right to the point. There is no Woman's Auxiliary in the Vatican and women are “eminently” more qualified than men to make decisions about women’s health care needs. Men have no authority on the matters of women's health.

The next time you read a letter by a bishop or cardinal, listen to a candidate who promises to repeal the Healthcare Act, or John Boehner, Mitch McConnell, or Michelle Bachman who say the American people don’t want or need the new bill, just remember all of the women in your life who have had breast, cervical, or ovarian cancer, terrible menstruation episodes, and menopause effects such as osteoporosis. These are the women who every day care for our children, parents and the elderly folks next door.

So the next time any man or woman opines about the attack on religious freedom and the needs of conscience, remind them that women need all of the breaks we can give them and just stop talking like that.
On the plus side, Rush has revealed a liking for the making and distribution of pornography - should he ever rant against that.

The Republican Party in my view has lost all sense of self awareness and objectivity and has become as fanatic and out of touch as political or religious group can be.

How is it in their interest to alienate the 98-99% of women in America who use or have used contraception. Do they actually believe that playing the "female card" will benefit them like their race card traditionally has. Do they realize that females vote in larger numbers than men and form a larger percentage of the electorate.
Do they think that Republican suburban soccer moms would accept this intrusion into their sexual freedom and health. Do men actually want their wives subjected to this kind of humiliation and intrusion by the government. Is it now the role of the government to regulate sexual behavior? This is madness.

Do Republicans really want to be associated with Rush Limbaugh as the face and voice of their party? Howard Stern, was threatened hounded and fined by the FCC for for using common idiomatic terms for genital organs in a playful and adolescent manner. What should be the response to Limbaugh for his calling a law student a "slut" for wanting contraception available and then saying that he wants all her sexual activity posted online for him to watch? He then attacked her parents. Where is the FCC?

Romney was exposed as a total morally vacuous and politically cowardly person
who was against this bill hours before he decided he supported it. Has he no shame?

Can any women vote GOP?

We can fix Social Security.  Remove the cap.  Why is income in excess of $106.000 exempt from the payroll tax?  There is no rational reason for it - it's simply another dodge for the very wealthy. There would be no increase in taxes, just extending the deduction to the very highest incomes.  This is one probem we can actually fix.

I bet when Krugman wrote the column he wasn't really expecting that someone who had apparently lived in that cave for the last 20 years would actually emerge just now to make a comment.

But here is holtxcrnr25, bellying up to the plague-on-both-your-houses indignation bar.

"How about actually having a surplus?!".

Um, holtxcrnr25, how to explain this? We did. Back in the Clinton administration, until it was done in by a combination of:

1. An unnecessary and unpaid for war or two. Afghanistan should have been a police action, not a war, and Iraq, well ... ;

2. An unfunded Medicare Part D, which would be a good program if it were funded and run by Medicare rather than an unholy alliance of of private sector insurance and drug companies;

3. The irresponsible Bush tax cuts which no one was asking for excerpt Bush's plutocratic enablers;

4. A financial crisis which was truly bi-partisan in its origins, but came to a head because of the Bush Administration's mania for de facto deregulation.

Obama's 2013 budghet is at least trying to start the process of digging us out of the mess while, as Krugman points out, the Four New Horsemen of the Apocalypse are heading off in the wrong direction.

Oh, and by the way, holttxcrnr25 should lose the canard about Social Security, which is bankrupting no one and, indeed, was used by Bush to coverup his financial irresponsibility.

What is it about a completely funded program, Social Security, that has been generating excess revenue for decades do you think needs reform? It has never added a penny of debt to our government, indeed by law it cannot, has lifted millions out of abject poverty in their old age and helps those who through misfortune can no longer work.

Yeah, we should just kill that program.

So, all that article really did was say, we're in huge debt, but if you elect these people, then we're going to be in even bigger debt, so only being in huge debt under Obama is better than being in possibly larger debt by someone else.

Let's get real, people. The only way we are going to fix the issues and eliminate debt is if we tackle Social Security and Medicare reform. Otherwise we have what Mr. Krugman just wrote about - an inevitable deficit, of which it may be slightly larger under one person rather than another. How about actually having a surplus?! It is not impossible, folks. If we enact the right policies and stop kicking the can down the road, in five years we could get back on track.

And the former are winning both legitimacy and elections. This is due in large measure to the mainstream media (obviosly not Krugmam) treating both sides as equally valid political positions.

Aside from the desire to "peddle papers," since when did distortion of fact and logic become a valid perspective? Answer: who cares?

Bottom line, no matter how logical Since when did denial of facts and logic

in the Once a party's mantra becomes "we are the champions of the stupid'," Why don't we just write off the 33-40% of us who

There is no squabbling more violent as that between people who accepted an idea yesterday and those who will accept the same idea tomorrow. -- Chistopher Darlington Morely

The enemy of my enemy is my friend. -- Arab Proverb

Somewhere between those two quotes, is the answer that you seek. But it's not Biblical; it's political. Which means it's about power and who sits on top of the trash heap. bc

There is so much fighting between religions, and I mean between Christian denominaions, so much disagreement between them, that I don't know how they could ever come together to decide how to run the government. Therefore, they are wrong.

it doesn't get any simpler than this.

Exactly right. The Republicans have forgotten how to participate in civil government. It used to be "politics ends at the American border". Now it is anything Obama does is bad.

We should withhold $40 million from their aid package.  10:1.  Our citizens are not pawns in your experiment with democracy.   And accusing the US of interference in your democratic process when that democratic process is being underwritten with OUR MONEY is assinine.  Yes, we expect something in return for our generosity.  A friend would recognize that expecting you to not using our citizens as pawns in return for our financial help is the action of a friend.  A better one than you'll get from any of other regimes in the region.

We will respect international treaties, only when the nations, in question, promote liberty and freedom for all their citizens and guests, in their country, Only when they give women rights, to drive, work, be educated, live a life of dignity and respect. If the US were to simply pick up and go, without any retaining force, there would be a difference: the myriad of extremist groups operating in the area, including the Taliban, would have free movement to the borders of Iran, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Uzebekistan, Turkmenistan, and China.  Meaning: the mobility of Islamic extremist networks is drastically increased throughout this crossroads region, leading to the likelihood of attacks througout the Middle East, Asia and the world.
